properties.name: #1 - Home
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh This is the house into which I was born. I spent 15 years in the tiny room at the end of the hall and moved into my sister\'s much larger room once she went off to university. When I was four I burned down my room. I built a tree-fort in the American Elm on the north side of the house and I once buried a time-capsule in the back yard but forgot to dig it up when we poured the concrete for our three-stall garage. Bummer. I never really appreciated this house when I was growing up in it. It was built in or around 1905 the evidence for which is in reeeeally old photos at Swedlund Photography and that the boiler in the basement had "1905" stamped on it. Now, I\'d really love to be able to live in a great big old house again.

properties.name: #10 - Quatama Crossing
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh I lived here for almost a year. It was nice to take the MAX to downtown where I worked. The 45 minutes on the train were a nice way to learn French. Though, once the real estate market shifted to a "buyers market" in 2003, all of the nice, caring, new family people from this place bolted to buy their first homes. Shortly after that the apartment complex new that it needed to keep their rooms full so they made a lot of their buildings government assisted. Not that there\'s really anything wrong with that, people need places to stay. But, when that happened the crime went up, vandalism and graphiti went up, dogs were shitting in the hall ways, unemployed men would hanging out in the parking lot all day without wearing any shirts. It was just kind of a bummer. It was fun throwing snap-its from the 3rd floor balcony to the sidewalk below and it was cool to have a swimmin\' pool. Ultimately, I just wanted to move downtown. Real Portland.

properties.name: #12 - Estelle Court First Apt
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh This place was awesome! It was downtown. I could walk everywhere. It was an old building with milk-delivery windows. The kitchen was fun to cook in and the hardwood floors were a dream. Also, this place was uphill from downtown where I worked so I could do that skateboard trick again where I get ready for work, go outside, put my board on the sidewalk and basically stand still all the way to work. Skateboarding uphill sucks though. S.W.A.S.S. From the front view of this building you can see the marquee outside of PGE park. That was always cool.

properties.name: #13 - Estelle Court Second Apt
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh This was the easiest move ever. I moved from an apartment on the second floor back to a new one on the second floor corner. I just loaded my shit up on a skateboard, did a little heave-ho action and boom! New apartment. It was basically the same as the one just before it but it was laid out better and it had a much better view from of the street. It was super weird and fun/interesting to be so close to the neighbors to the building just to the east of me though. You never know if someone can see you running from the shower to the kitchen in the buff (sometimes I\'d forget I put toast in the toaster).

properties.name: #14 - The Retro Church
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh I lived here with Paul Alcott of Binary Dolls and Datr for a few months. He was really cool to live with, literally and figuratively -- the place was freezing and Paul is an interesting guy. Paul let me borrow a bicycle of his so I could get to/from work (the days of skateboarding to work were long gone) but the bicycle provided quite a wonderful lot of freedom. The guys from Binary Dolls were over nearly every day. We invented a tiddily-winks-esque game called Black from the Dead which involved bouncing poker chips into a cup in the center of a dining table. Genius. One thing that was really cool was that I was living here while Binary Dolls were recording "Too Much Thinking Sinks Ships" which, incidentally, and independent of this experience, has become one of my favorite music albums. I sincerely urge you to check it out.

properties.name: #15 - The AB House
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh   Oh, the AB house. This was the band house of the Altarboys, thus the title AB. I lived here longer than any other place in stumptown. It was truly great. Everyone who lived there at the time of us all moving in were somehow recently single so we were out at the bars every night. To avoid getting fat from all of the drinking I rode my bike downtown to work virtually every day and I used to love to run to the waterfront and back or I\'d jog up to Mt. Tabor. This house was a dump but I friggin\' loved it. It was loud, fun, fast, and dirty: just like the Altarboys music. Here\'s a clip from one of their old songs. Somewhere around 37 seconds there\'s a shot of me chucking a beer at Smiley during our New Years 2006 party. Good times.

properties.name: #16 - 24th and Johnson
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh This place was weird, but it was a nice break from the hazy, crazy days of the AB house. I needed to unwind from a bit of drama that came up while I lived at AB so I found myself back in NW. When I moved in here there was a really awesome French guy who taught at the Portland French school and a kinda lame guy who was a financial analyst at the Standard, Kirby. Unfortunately the cool French guy moved out after a month and his replacement, Lauren moved in. Eech. We didn\'t get along very well. Ultimately, Kirby and Lauren wanted the place to themselves so they kicked me out saying that I was disrespectful. That sucked. But I got over it. A few months after I moved out I saw that they moved out anyway because house was being remodeled. Either way, I\'ve never had such awful roommates.

properties.name: #17 - The Elizabeth
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh Aaaaah, alone again. I lived in this studio for about a year and NEVER should have moved. Though, the way my life shook out after moving was quite wonderful (I fell in love at the place just after this and am now in a newer, nicer, place in both real estate and love are concerned) but this place was sweet. It was small because it was a studio, but it was close to everything and I loved riding my scooter all over town from this location. Elephant\'s was close by and my friend Nikki would go there on Sundays. It got amazing light in the mornings and the balcony (read: fire escape) was fun to have outside. Every morning I\'d do freelance work before going to the office and this awkward lady would awkwardly jog up 22nd ave. She just looked AWKWARD... but she was a part of the neighborhood. I haven\'t seen her since. The only reason I moved was because the building was being sold to KBC and I knew my rent was going to skyrocket, which was a bummer because it sucks to pay a lot of money for such a small apartment. Also, I wanted to move to France so I figured I\'d shack up with friends in NE before shipping out.

properties.name: #18 - Wygant We Be Friends?
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh This. Place. Was. Fun. I lived here with Jess and Kari and we threw the best parties, had a ton of fun cooking in the kitchen, and just got along really well. It was nice to have relate-able roommates again. The kitchen of this place was clearly it\'s heart. Lotsa chrome, lotsa granite, lots of boiling pots for pasta. Also, this is where I met Kirsten, in that very kitchen. When I moved into 12th and Wygant We Be Friends I had planned on saving money to move to France but I ended up quitting my day-job to do contract web design full time (the new Platial website looks pretty nice, doesn\'t it? ;o) Eventually our lease ran out but I didn\'t save up enough to go to Paris so I just moved back over to the NW side. The lawn here was a bitch. I always like the idea of doing yard work but when it really comes down to it, I just didn\'t like spending my time on it. We\'d let the grass get a foot and a half tall before doing anything about it then I\'d spend all friggin\' afternoon unloading bags of grass.

properties.name: #19 - 23 Hoyt
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh This place was a dump, but I had really great roommates. The landlord inherited the house from his grandmother and basically lives off of the rent of the house. It\'s ,500 a month to rent, the tenants pay utilities so the landlord can just ride off of the wages from the place. The only sad part is that the house is in dire need for love. It could be a really cool place but it was just so run down. The house next door was virtually identical to ours, except the owner obviously had a bit of money in his back pocket and a subscription to Dwell magazine. Standing on 23 Hoyt and looking at the two houses is like looking at Dufus and Gallant. I should have moved into Gallant. Ew. That\'s kinda gross. I\'ve always wanted to buy this house and make it my own but the landlord won\'t sell. He could make a pretty shiny penny off of it, but he\'d rather just cash the rent checks. I don\'t really blame him, but it is a shame that such a wonderful house is going to shit without the attention it deserves. Moving on, though, this neighborhood is my favorite of all of Portland. You can have your Albertas and your Hawthornes. Me? I prefer the yuppie shops and fancy plates that fly from this corner of the world. I sure do miss walking to Noah\'s every morning for my coffee and it was nice to have Escape from NY pizza right across the street. Either way, though, it was a pit, but fun. We had a crazy-awesome Halloween party and there was a prefect little gap by the side of the house where I could park my scooter.

properties.name: #2 - My Aunt's House in Nebraska
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh I lived here with my Aunt and Uncle in Seward, Nebraska while I worked for my Uncle\'s corn detassling company: The Sloup-Thorrell Corn Company. It was nice. I stayed in the basement every summer for four years while working in the fields all around Seward, York, Waco, and the likes. We\'d get up at 4 or so in the morning, get ready, go to Seward High, board a bus, drive an hour to a field somewhere, wait until legal sun-up, work for 12 hours, get home, rinse off the mud, take a shower, pass out, have dinner, hang out with friends, pass out again and start over. It was great. Also, rollerblading was just getting some steam and it was cool to blade all over Seward. Though my Aunt\'s house was on a street that was entirely paved with bricks. Not. Cool. But still kind of neat.

properties.name: #20 - The House of Stewart
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh This is where I currently live. I\'ve only been here for a week or so, but it\'s absolutely wonderful. Christina and her cousin (my girlfriend) Kirsten live here. There are always fun and thematic dinner parties, celeb-related tv shows on the tube and plenty of whole-wheat, spelt, sugar-free goodies around. Bella and Elanor "Rigs" Rigby keep me company throughout the day while I do my contract work and the view of the city is amazing. More to come on this one...

properties.name: #3 - Werner Hall at Bismarck State
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh  Here\'s where I did my first year of college. I lived in the dorms with a Montanan named Pete before taking a room at the end of the hall with Scott, a nice Democrat from Drake. It was aaight. Bunk beds were an interesting touch, but they made me feel like a child. Of course, now that I\'m lurking on being 10 years out from my freshman year in college, I realize that I WAS a child. Fitting. Also, the RA was kind of a dick. Scott was cool though. Mostly, I was just bummed that they didn\'t have a track team.

properties.name: #4 - My First Apartment
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh I lived here with one of my fellow graphic design classmates, Bryce. It was rad, though I always felt bad that I was dirt broke even though I was working at the college for my work-study program, at Blockbuster and at my internship at Spit\'n Image. He was super cool to live with and we had a riot. Also, he was 21 and I was not. Niiice. We had a grill that we kept outside and it was super cool to be so close to the park where I\'d run a nice 5k route three times a week. Also, it was cool to be so close to the mini golf course and the tennis courts. I can\'t believe I actually needed a car to live in Bismarck. Ah well, every one drives everywhere there.

properties.name: #5 - My First Time Living Alone
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh This. Place. Was. Awesome. It was the basement, 1 bedroom apartment in a super old house replete with spiders, my own fridge, glass doorknobs, the whole nine. I lived here from winter of 99 until fall of 2000. That summer Butz and Jimmy Nelson and I hung out every day, driving around in the blue ZX2, goin mini-golfing, drinking Cold One 22s and playing Dot Darts... which is when you throw gummy Dots at the windshields of passing cars. It was the best summer of my life. I bask in that summer.

properties.name: #6 - Cottonwood First Time
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh I lived here with Julie, a super cool lady I worked with at Kranzer Kingsley and our other roommate who\'s name I CAN NEVER FRIGGIN\' REMEMBER. This place was all right. I turned 21 while I lived here. The day before that Cole Bernhard and I drank Jim Beam Dr. Peppers until I dry heaved in the bathroom. Cole covered me up with an afghan that my mom made for me and I stared at the base of the toilet from the tile. It was cool. I liked cooking in the kitchen and grilling on the patio. The roomies and I had some fun together drinking and watching tv and stuff, but mostly we kept to ourselves in our own rooms. I got kinda fat living here. I went through this horrible yet awesome habit of eating rows and rows of Oreos while watching free movies I\'d rent from Blockbuster while I worked there. Oreo\'s were an issue with my belly. Man I love them. I started running longer distances after that.

properties.name: #7 - Avenue C
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh I lived in the basement of this house alone for quite a while. It was pretty cool living here. Being right across the street from a high school was kind of a downer though. Hearing kids roll up to school with their Rockford Fosgates kicking as loudly as possible at 7am is not the best trip, and there was never a place to park during the day. My neighbors were this struggling young 20\'s couple who would SCREAM at one another but always be entirely pleasant with me when they realized I was in the laundry room. The other really cool thing was that this place is uphill from Kranzler Kingsly on Main and 5th so I could basically get on my skateboard, stand still and roll all the way to work. I used to try to see if I could get there in the shortest number of kicks. Also, the clinic in my back yard had an awesome sidewalk and stairs for doing skateboard tricks on. I hurt myself on their property more than I care to admit.

properties.name: #8 - Cottonwood Second Time
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh This is where I lived for the couple of months leading up to moving to Portland. Not too much to report here because I didn\'t live here too long, but it was the first time that I ever lived with a girlfriend. Sinner.

properties.name: #9 - My first place in Portland
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh I thought this place was okay, but my girlfriend at the time thought it was a dump. We lived here for four days. That, pretty much sucked.

properties.name: Backspace
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh  115 Nw 5th Ave, Portland, OR, 97209This is a chill coffee-shop to work on freelance projects in the morning. Good music, good coffee and usually some really great art hanging on the walls.

properties.name: Billy Ray's Neighborhood Dive
properties.description: Posted by Kaptinqwin  2216 NE MLK Blvd Portland OR 97212 billy\'s is stumbling distance to my house. they have cheap beer, pool, pinball and sometimes ping pong. pretty mixed crowd, no liquor, nice roomy upstairs.

properties.name: Chez Moi
properties.description: Posted by MatthewstrohThis is my home.

properties.name: Finish the 2007 Portland Marathon
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh  This was my third marathon and...uh... well, I didn\'t do so hot. I\'ve learned that you can\'t just put in a few miles here and there and try to run a successful marathon. Real training must be done. The muscles just above my knees started to lock up around mile 20... that wasn\'t fun because it made me not able to bend my legs. All in all, though, I love running marathons. The finish is always worth it.

properties.name: Gold Rush
properties.description: Posted by MatthewstrohNE ML King Blvd, Portland, OR

properties.name: Goldie's
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh 2601 NE MLK Jr Blvd, Portland, OR 97212Rad little hangout. They even have an old school Cattlemen board game. Nice. Also, the folks behind the counter almost always seem to be in a great mood... Why is that?

properties.name: Graham and 7th Roundabout
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh

properties.name: Here I was!
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh I heard people honking their horns as they drove up MLK for no less than three hours after McCain conceeded. It was intense. I then went to abcnews.go.com to watch the speeches.

properties.name: Knott Street Grocery
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh

properties.name: Ladds Circle
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh This fantastic, rose garden filled roundabout is a nice landmark for going on one of my staple "out to Mt. Tabor and back" long runs.

properties.name: Lil Kim fan in the PDX
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh

properties.name: Matthew Stroh
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh2808 NE M L King Blvd, Portland ORI {heart} Menomena.

properties.name: Matthew Stroh
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstrohportland

properties.name: My Aunt's Back Yard
properties.description: Posted by MatthewstrohI used to spend hours mowing this lawn with a push mower. I stayed in Seward, NE every summer during high school while I worked as a corn detassler.

properties.name: Noah's Bagles
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh

properties.name: Noahs Bagels
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh This is where I get my coffee most days of the week. They have a brew called Chelsea (named after the Manhattan neighborhood - not the horrible football club in Fullham) which is the most wonderful cup I can find in all of Portland. Sadly, Chelsea isn\'t local. Sorry, stumptown.

properties.name: PGE Park, Home of the Timbers!
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh  This is where I go to yell as loud as I can at my very own, hometown football club, the Portland Timberrrrs!

properties.name: Pearl Bakery
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh  Great French coffees and breads.

properties.name: Port of Portland Boat
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh  I try to run on the waterfront for each of my long runs and I always notice this boat. It\'s a museum, I think, maybe someday I should go. I also really love the Port of Portland logo. I\'m not really into getting Nike or Adidas tattooed anywhere on my body, but I\'d really like to get the Port of Portland logo tattooed somewhere on me -- JUST BECAUSE I like running by this place.

properties.name: Portland, Maine
properties.description: Posted by MatthewstrohLanding here would have been top notch.

properties.name: Respond2
properties.description: Posted by MatthewstrohI worked as a production artist / web designer and developer at Respond2 for four years and continue to do so as an independent contractor.

properties.name: Roseland
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh Concerts I\'ve Been to at Roseland: Ozomatli Ray Lamontagne Sum 41 Zwan Cursive

properties.name: Russel St. BBQ
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh 2601 NE MLK Jr Blvd, Portland, OR 97212Amazing ribs, briskets and sauces. Their shrimp appetizer (bisque-like dish) is my favorite resuaurant food ithm of all time.

properties.name: Starbucks
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh555 Sw Oak St, Portland, OR

properties.name: Starbucks
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh 555 Sw Oak St, Portland, OR

properties.name: Statue of Harey W. Scott
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh I love this guy at the top of Mt. Tabor! He\'s part of the inspiration to run to the top of the hill. While I\'m trekking up the mount I actually use "get to the top of Harvey Scott" as a mantra to make sure I make it up there. That\'s kind of annoying now that I\'m actually writing this it seems kind of annoying... but it helps me get to the top of the hill. Reminds me of the statue from The Simpsons.

properties.name: Stewart Cleaners Dry Cleaning
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh Alterations and dry cleaning.

properties.name: The Daily Café
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh  A trendy place to find Illy coffee, great sandwiches and a modern athmosphere

properties.name: matthewstroh - G Unit Fan
properties.description: Posted by Matthewstroh
